Fun flavors begin with vanilla and bourbon, then meander through gentle peaks of medium-roasted coffee beans. Toasty, slightly burnt, sophisticated, classy. A cigar-friendly brew.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2008 Bottle at LCRBM08. Very nice liquorice flavour. Black colour. Big stable light brown head. Mild carbonation, served slightly warm which suits it very well. 8 4 8 4 16

Bottle, 11%. Sweet and vinous liquorice aroma. Almost black colour, seems clear. Small brown head. Good roasted and burnt flavour. A hint of tar and smoke comes on later. The flavour is quite sweet, balances off some of the distinct flavours as well as the alcohol. The mouthfeel gets a little thick from all the sugar, but does not get too sticky or syrupy. Mild and soft carbonation. 8 4 9 4 17

Bottle @ LCRBM 08: Poured a dark black brown with a thin tan color head. The aroma is liquorice, dark fruits, and coffee. The taste is sweet with fruits and liquorice, some bitter spices in the finish that create a warming along with the alcohol.

(Bottled, 0.75l) Almost black with a medium, very tight, lasting and lacy, beige head. Complex and pleasant aroma of sweetish, roasted malt, lots of licorice, black coffee, dried fruit, some burned notes and hints of alcohol. Strongly roasty, lightly burned flavor with lots of balancing malt sweetness, some smokiness, herbs and spices, dandelion, and a strong, lingering bitterness drying towards the end. No signs of alcohol in the flavor. Very full and luscious body, with the medium carbonation making it less thick and easier to drink. Leaves some stickiness, though. A huge and complex Imperial porter. There must be truckloads of color malt in this, but its beautifully hidden. Delicious stuff!

Small off-white rim over red-brown, dark cognac colour. Very fruity nose, alcohol obvious, dark berries aromas. Sweet taste (certainly for a porter), with liquorice, fusels, herbs like rosemary. Complex, yet well-balanced. Ends on liquorice mixed with walnut. Well-bodied, lots of alcoholwarming, slick. Nice, if sweet-alcoholic porter.

Courtesy of Fonefan, who cracked this open, but also thank you to Bierkoning from whom I have bottle # 52. This is Bottle # 298 of 823. It’s a black beer with a creamy head. The aroma is complex with notes of licorice, roasted malt, dark fruits and a hint of alcohol. The flavour has a light sweetness and a light bitterness. It has notes of licorice, coffee, caramel, peat, dark fruits, citrus and it ends on a dry note. It’s very complex and the flavour lingers for a very long time  truly nice. Its worthy # 4500 for me!

Bottle, sampled at RBSG 08. Pours a deep black with a tan ring. Deep burnt malt aroma, with hints of dark fruit. Big burnt, toasted malt taste, with a bit of alcohol. Lingering burnt flavors. Very nice imperial porter.

Bottled@Fonefan. A perfect ending to two very nice days around in Ulfborg! Very dark rubyish brown colour (close to black) with small creamy brown head that stays for a while. Aroma is raisins, smoked wood, some peat, mild smoke as well as some slight fruityness. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, licorice, alcohol as well as some mildly smoked wet wood. Really complex and wellbalanced. Fullbodied.
Bottle. Pours a black brown body with no head.  Coffee nutty brown, peanuts and dry minerals.  Okay.

#458  11/07 @Richmond/Williamsburg Gathering-33 cl bottle-pours with no head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-roasty, slight vegetal, dark fruit.  Taste is vinuous, dark malt-roasty, slight vegetal, dark fruit, some salt/acidic.  Thanks dkachur/Dan for sharing.

RBSG 2008. Pours dark brown with a soft tan head that fades fast. Very smoky and earthy, heavy burnt flavors give an impression of BBQ’d steak, some charred hefty concoction. Finish has a touch of saltiness, that when mixed with the charred flavors brings out a touch of soy sauce.

Richmond Summer Gathering. Bottled 1NOV07, #458, courtesy of dkachur. Black with no head. Mild nose, roasty malt, chocolate, raisin, a whiff of smoke. Excellent body - slick and satiny. Slightly burnt malt flavors, chocolate and a touch of licorice. Just a bit of saltiness in there somewhere. Excellent!

Bottle at the Williamsburg Gathering courtesy of dkachur. Labeled #458. Near black dark brown pour. Absolutely no head on this except a larger bubble or two. Nose is soy sauce, roasted malts, salt, dark chocolate and cocoa. Taste is salty and soy sauce-like with more roasted malts, slight burnt coffee and light dark fruit. Body is near flat but has a nice slickness and is velvety smooth going down. Ends with hops and licorice, soft chocolate, soy sauce, and some odd herbalness. A unique Baltic porter!

Bottle #458 courtesy of bierkoning. Thanks Edo! Shared at the 2008 Richmond Summer Gathering in Williamsburg. Bottled 11/11/07. Very dark brown pour with a small head. Roasty aroma with notes of alcohol, soy and subtle hops. Taste of chocolate, soy and smoke. Very sticky texture.

12oz bottle, Bottle date/number 1NOV07/458. Thanks to dkachur at Richmond Summer Gathering @ Williamsburg. Pours pour black in color with brwon head. Aroma chocolate and coffee. Taste roasted coffee, chocolate and fruity with bitter finish.

thanks to solan for sharing at rbsg 2008

nice complex chocolate, roasty, complex flavor. Very tasty.

At the brewery pub. A dark black colored beer, with a great thick foamy beige head. It leaves a nice lace on the glass. The aroma of pure chocolate and coffee, dark, dried fruits. The taste is also from pure chocolate and coffee, dark fruits like prune. That makes it a nice little sweet. It has a long little bitter aftertaste. A very good beer. This one belongs with the best beers.

A vigorous pour leaves only the most pitiful of bubbles.  Given a minute, the beer is completely still looking.  Relatively thick dark, dark brown/black body.

Dark chocolate, molasses, tobacco in the smell.

Molasses, chocolate and funky dark fruits in the flavor.  Vinous.  Tar (in a good way) and tobacco.  Herbs.  Espresso.  Definitely complex and interesting.  

Mouthfeel is thick with virtually no carbonation.  Oily.  Slightly alcoholic.  

Very interesting, and altogether quite tasty, beer.  This one really doesn’t fit any one style perfectly.  Probably best not to go in expecting a traditional Baltic Porter.
No head at all, flat in fact. Flavor is heavy in tobacco, anise and chocolate. some espresso but nothing special.

(Bottle thanks to Jeppe, one of the most friendly and generous reatbeerians out there) Pours black with brown lines and no head. The aroma is of light to medium sticky sweetness, medium roasted/burned malt and some vinous notes with tones of dark chocolate, dark berries, some blue mature grapes, black currant, light smoke, dark syrup, light caramel, wet stone, anise/sal ammoniac, dried fruits. and some light hints of limey/grassy/herbal hops. The flavour is of strong and spicy espresso, cocoa, liquorice and anise up front with vinous undertones. Other notable tones are wet stone, light dry smokiness, dark fruits/prunes, dark syrup alongside grassy and tiny citric hops. The mouthfeel is dry, soft and tiny sticky. Light to medium sweet and medium bitter. Some alcohol warmth. Medium to full bodied.

BottleThinkin Bout Thirteen Hours O Drinkin (tew man wrecking crew)... Pours pitch black with a quickly diminishing, fat bubbled, light brown head. All kinds of stuff going on here. The nose presents earthy leather, canvas and tobacco notes along with malty chocolate and subtle herbal musings of sassafras, sarsaparilla and fennel. Medium to full-bodied. So very rich; sweet and spicy; chocolaty and herbal. Moderate charcoal bitterness compliments chocolate sweetness. Finishes bittersweet, chocolaty and spicy. Ultra-complex. Strange, but very good! Thanks to Magic_dave6 for providing the bottle!

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a dark brown/black, with not much of a head.  Some light clear bubbles hug the edge of the glass.  Smells of dark chocolate, some traces of dark fruit, alcohol heat, and a hint of vanilla and wood as well.  The flavor was full bodied, lightly carbonated, with a pretty noticeable alcohol presence.  A bit oily on the palate, there were big doses of roasted malts, and burnt chocolate.  Nice bitter finish. with a woodsy, roasty aftertaste.  Pretty nice big beer.  Well done.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Somewhat transparent, dark brown colored pour with a thin layer of bubbly beige head.  

A huge toffee malt aroma jumps out of the glass instantly to me, along with some mild pear esters.  Dark malt 

aromas of chocolate, raisins, and mildly toasted nuts as well.  There appears to be some mild oxidation going on, 

but this seems to be mixed in with the fruity esters.  This certainly doesnt smell like a lager, but its passable as an Imperial Porter, as the label claims.  Medium bodied, lightly carbonated mouthfeel with 

a sugary sweetness.  Sweet toffee and caramel up front on the palate, accompanied by some flambeed raisin and 

spicy hops.  It seems a touch thin with oxidation, which tends to enhance the sweetness of the beer, bringing 

forth more of a "sugary" impression than a "malty" impression.  Mid-palate, the flavors grow in intensity, 

revealing a moderate chocolate roastiness and mild smokiness thats quite pleasant.  As the beer warms, the flavors seem to integrate a 

bit better, developing more impressive flavors in the finish.  Ill be the first to admit that I suffered a bit 

of disappointment initially due to the expecation of a Baltic Porter, but I feel my rating reflects how I feel 

about this beer as an Imperial Porter.  Thanks for sharing, Ryan!

Oh, man. Im sort of at a loss for words on this. Heres what I know for sure, heavy tobacco and chocolate. Bitter and semi oaky. Lots of flavors and overall a very well put together beer. Way above average but not quite world class.

Bottle.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige ehad.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel and liquorice with notes of dried fruits.
Sweet and roasted flavour of caramel and liquorice with notes of chocolate and dried fruits.
Roasted and warming alcoholic finish.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle.  Oily chocolate brown, not overly dense.  Punchy citrus and pineapple aroma with a deep, imposing undertow of chocolate, caramel and roasty tobacco; lively hints of raisin and cherry providing some vinous touch.  Nuances are kindly restrained, the body full and warm; complex and amicable aroma.  Rich malt flavor with a sticky vegetal astringency of unroasted espresso beans suggesting foliage and raw salad greens; this is permeating but not wholly off putting, withering to the thinnest of powdery coating on this burly body of ashy chocolate malt, grahams and surprisingly, bitter citrus acids.  Somewhat floral and dryly earthy, with an lovely waft of mossy smoke gathering strength.  Palate is full and oily, uncarbonated; finish dries out with smoke and bitter wood; erudite impression in the end from this detailed offering.  Thanks Eric!

Thanks moejuck/miketd:  Aroma is roasted chocolate malts, alcoholic undertones.  Flavor is mild smokiness, ashy, and dry but warm chocolate finish.  Would be tasty but the smokiness seemed to not blend with the rest of the flavor here.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: [Shared at WLV tasting 4/5/08]  Pours dark black/brown with thin brown head. Sweet roasted malt aroma with plenty of smoke.  Flavor of smoked peat, candied belgian malt, chocolate with a dry finish.  Considerable sticky syrupy body.  I really enjoyed this one and hope to some day have another taste!

Courtesy SoLan.  Lifeless near-black pour.  Nice aroma - sweet roast, tannins, alcohol.  Aggressive and roasty aroma.  Bitter roast on the taste, but still smooth, with the alcohol complimenting the tastes present.  Some clean nutty tastes come in.  A real nice Baltic.
(sample from irishboy)dark brown with red highlights.smoke chocolate,cocoa,and pine hops is what i get from it.mouthfeel is thin.
Black, no head.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, smoke, alcohol.  Taste is chocolate, caramel, alcohol, dried fruit.  Nice thick body.
330ml bottle; Nose of coffee, chocolate, caramel and light floral hops; black with a very small beige head; flavor of light hop bitterness, caramel, and chocolate.

12 oz bottle, via jbrus.  Pours a very dark brown body with just a few large bubbles clinging to the outside of the glass.  The nose is roasty and smokey with lots of burnt malt and a hint of alcohol.  A little bit of hoppiness as well.  The flavor is heavy roast with some smoke and soy oxidation notes.  A little bit of alcohol, but not much for an 11% beer.  Chocolate, cocoa, maybe even a bit of leather.  A lot going on here.  Mouthfeel is perfect for me, very minimal carbonation gives it a great viscous oily smooth texture.  Overall, very nice, just my kind of beer.  A little bit of an odd ball for a Baltic, not quite as much on the licorice that I like, but I give it credit for being a little unique.

Courtesy bierkoning. Bottle #568. Black/dark brown. No head. Aroma of earth, roast, dry grains, tobacco, bittersweet cocoa, nuts, graham cracker, subtle alcohol. Huge dark chocolate in the flavor with the same notes from the aroma. Rich. Intense. Full body, smooth. Excellent.

Courtesy SoLan.  Pours a nearly totally black color.  Aroma is odd.  Very nutty and chocolatey.  A great roasted note comes through nicely.  The flavor is much more intense than I anticipated, with a huge roasted bitterness on the finish.  Vwry nice.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with almost no head. Sweet aroma of dried fruits, choclate, coffee and lots of roasted malts. Pretty sweet taste, dark caramel, followed by an intense bitterness, both from roasted malts as from hop. Virtually not carbonated, which is a pity, otherwise it would have been really great. Now it is just a great beer.

Had this with dinner tonight, at the brewery.

  At first, I was disappointed they had no TIK, Tien, or Rasputin.  But WOW!

  Its got a LOT of everything. Complex, deep, rich, perfect head and smells like a beer should. 

  I would have bought a case, but they were sold out.  Competes with the best Belgian Beers in my fridge (West Vlet 12, St. Bernardus ABT, Rochefort 10.)

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via un échange avec Chouffegnome99. Arôme: Odeur de torréfaction avec une pointe danis. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Saveur: Goût de chocolat et de caramel avec une pointe de petits fruits foncés. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture sirupeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Alcool en arrière goût. (Rating #1624)

My Bottom Line:
The controlled sweetness of aniseed and vanilla swims in warming alcohol until an abrasive finishing bitterness provides plenty of roastiness and hoppiness for this atypical Baltic Porter.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam barely surrounds the brown-sleeved black; even if I swirled the beer in the glass, it could not muster any decent head.
-The aroma was not really inviiting (nor intense); I really had to dig into it to find a few objects of interest.
-The mouthfeel is slick and rather loose, not helped by the nearly dormant carbonation.
-That spicy sweetness is almost minty at times.
-There arent too many residual sugars in here, which is nice, but I didnt find lots of mindblowing maltiness either. The body is rather slender for a beer this size.
-This tasted like it needed a lot more time to become more cohesive.

Bottle; thx Marc et Éric!

12oz bottle shared at west lakeview this past weekend..... poured a dark brown, considerably darker than de molens impy stout, with a wispy head.... aroma of black licorice, chocolate, and a little roast that was followed up with dark, roasty smoked chocolate which was semi-watery but ultimately went down well.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 33cl bottle. pours black with no head. aroma of bakers chocolate. flavors are loaded with bakers chocolate, coffee roast. really smooth around the edges. alcohol is very well hidden. yummy!

Bottle thanks to kramer17801. Aroma is a really intense, complex individual character. Theres an interesting depth that comes as unique, bready mature yeast character, but nothing bad. Its just so fragrant, delicate and nuanced. Mature, chocolately, bright and crisp. It has that extra edge of something I can explain that puts it in an upper echelon of unique quality. I think the high level of hopping contributes to the beauty of the aroma, but it melds really well. Pours a dense oily black, with very little head. Flavor continues in the vein of the nose. Theres some warm spiced bread, dark fruit jams, then a good run of chocolate and coffee. Immeadiately, Im reminded of Mikkeller X Imperial Stout, for having the faintest edge of funk. Dense, nutty and sweet. Im not overwhelmed by stickiness or alcohol, which makes this really special. Theres distinct fresh roast character that originates from Cashews, toasted breads, and caramel. Finishes clean and long drawing. I could sip this for hours. Dense and packed with flavor. A really nice example. Worthy of its status.

Sampled by bottle at West Lake View Tasting.  Im glad I got to try this, especially since Im told this wont be coming to America at all.  Pours brown black with almost no head.  Nose is strong and rich.  Chocolate, roasted malts, and molasses.  Sweet chocolate flavors.  Caramels, alcohol, dark chocolate, and anise.    Charred and toasted grains in the finish.  Im not blown away, but overall its a really good beer.

12oz bottle, courtesy of kramer17801.  Thanks, Jason!  Pours an oily, dark chocolate color; solid viscosity; mostly headless.  Gorgeous aroma: oily peanuts, roasted malts, a touch of salt, and maple syrup in the aroma; all beautifully integrated; loads of roasted chocolate and salty/sweet oiliness.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of oily peanuts, roasted / charred malts, and lots of dense, gooey chocolate; minimal carbonation; loads of dark chocolate, dried fruits, and chewy, oily peanuts; nice citrus and general bittering hops to balance things out; very oily, very full of chocolate; impressively dense, with very little alcohol showing through.  Lengthy finish, showing oily chocolate, cocoa, and plenty of nuts and peanuts; cocoa and dry toasted grains.

Courtesy of kramer17801. Dark brown body with a small tan head. Sweet, raisin nose with molasses, cola and milk chocolate. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with milk chocolate, juicy plums, roast, toffee and light cherry. Medium/full body is soft with light carbonation. Finish is long with a bit of warmth.

For rating #400.  Thanks very much to Jason.  Black bodied with a froth of bubbles formed.  Aroma is a sweet licorice, vanilla, and chocolate.  Flavor is a roasted bitter licorice, and chocolate primarily.  Alcohol is noticeable in the finish.  Thin and watery body.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 330ml bottle shared by kramer17801.  Pours a dark brown with little to no head.  Sticky sweet nose of motor oil, some smoke, some rich, sticky malt, a lack of overbearing hops, which is really nice.  Sticky, smooth, sweet, rich, decadent chocolate and syrupy malty goodness along with some moderately strong alcohol which adds to the whole experience.  Rich, sticky, sweet up front, drying into the finish.  Really well made, the sweetness thats found in most Dutch beer is certainly there, and it works really well.  I like it.

(3/16/08) Bottle bought at Brouwerij de Molen in Bodegraven and drank at a friends house in Amsterdam. Black color, not totally opaque, with no head and just a bit of brown foam. Strong aroma of dark chocolate, some espresso notes, a bit of licorice, a bit of hops and faint hints of alcohol. Flavor starts sweet with malt, chocolate, caramel and a bit of dark fruits and finishes with a strong hops and roasty bitterness. Full-bodied and syrupy, maybe even a bit like melted chocolate. Really great stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2016 Thanks Jan (from De Bierkoning) for hand delivering this Bottle #101. What an amazing porter; aroma was roasted malt with slight Smokey flavors, strong licorice, more alcohol aroma as it warmed.  I had plenty of frothy brown head after the initial pour. Taste was outstanding for this porter; full-bodied with plenty of bitter chocolate, coffee, slight tobacco flavor with an oily feel; very drinkable considering how high the alcohol level. Cant wait to get some more of this stuff!

12oz bottle #224 from kramer17801. Very lucky to get this without having to spend a fortune trading overseas.  High fill bottle.  No pop when the cap was removed.  I was told this leads to undercarbonation (as this beer was flat) in naturally carbonated beers, and also prevents mellowing with age, which would be desirable in this beer.  Pours thick and black with a heavy body.   Aroma is powerful despite the lack of carbonation.  Lots malty notes with figs and prunes abounding.  As strong as the aroma is, it pales in comparison to the first sip:  Like soaking a leather belt in pipe tobacco and prune juice, then chewing on the belt.  Flavors abound.  Actually pretty nice and fun to drink.  I wish the carbonation level was higher and it had another 6 months of age, or put into a barrel or something.  Mega-potential. 4.1-4.2.

12oz bottle #224 from wetherel brought to the PP Carlsbad Bottle shop tasted with deftim13 and bikesandbeer.  Really crazy beer.  Pours black with a little head.  Nose is sweet and leathery.  Taste is huge with notes of leather, tobacco and smoke, very intense and somewhat overwhelming.  Overall an interesting beer Im glad I could try.

Bottle #27.  Poured opaque black with a bronze edge and legs but no head.  The aroma is of roasted malt and bitter dark chocolate.  Notes of unsmoked cigar as well.  Roasted malt and more dark chocolate make up the flavor.  The choclate starts to  turn to a milk style toward the finish.  Bitterness on the dry finish.  Full creamy body.  Some chest warmth is provided.

Appearance: Lazily pours out an opaque, inky black body. No amount of swirling, shaking, or verbal abuse can raise a bubble of carbonation from its depths.

Smell: Roasted malt aroma with notes of barley, bakers chocolate, and licorice liqueur. 

Taste: Richly roasty and certainly sweet. Hint of scorched grains. A taste reminiscient of bitter herbs and wood run loose amongst the other tastes of chocolate, licorice, molasses. A bit of smoke on the long bittersweet finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium body that takes on an oily feel due to the absence of carbonation.

Drinkability: All in all, it really is a fine beer.

Bottle #40 thanks to jbrus via kramer17801:  Pours an opaque oily black with a thin ring of light tan bubbles.  Complex aroma of dark chocolate, mint, tobacco and earthy smoky peat.  Body starts fairly rich, but quite still, with a good amount of dark caramel and chocolate sweetness and a touch of light fruity ester complexity.  Has some peaty smoky flavor toward a slightly drier and warming bittersweet finish with lingering smoke and dark chocolate.  Leafy tobacco notes come through more as it warms.  Very complex throughout and would be great with a little more carbonation.

Bottle #40:  Pours a deep almost opaque brown color with no head.  Aroma is malty, toffee, chocolate, roast, alcohol, and some spicy hops.  Flavor is caramel, plum, toffee, roast, a hint of coffee, alcohol, and a bitter peppery finish.

Bottle. #233. Black colour with a nice brown head. Mild aroma of sweet malt, roastedness, chocolate and dry coffee. Flavour of coffee, alcohol and roastedness. Ends up quite alcoholic and nearly just coffee.

Black body with a medium sized big bubbled brown head; Amazing nose, super intense but still elegant and secretive, a nice soft warmth is peaking out from the otherwise quite strict nose; Super soft body with very little but the right amount of carbonation, there is a sharp strict bitter bite and lots of balanced sweet and salt, amazing depth, complexity and balance; Long sharp and soft finish, it bites a bit and it is perfectly balanced with the soft texture, great warm and sharp aromas. Elegant deep and complex beer that is very, very well composed. Thanks!!!

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Draught @ Brouwerij de Molen, Bodegraven, Netherlands. Clear dark brown color with a large, creamy - rocky, excellent lacing, fully lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, moderate hoppy, grass, moderate to heavy english licorice, notes of smoke in the finish. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long long duration. Body is full, texture is creamy - oily - syrupy, carbonation is soft. Very very nice ;o)) 9-5-9-5-18 (030308)

Bottle 75cl. Clear dark black color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, dark berry, vanilla, licorice, moderate peat. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Very rich and complex flavor. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, creamy, syrupy, carbonation is soft - flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. Very nice work Menno ;o)) 8-4-8-5-18 (250208)

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 A Mes rate: Bottle thrust into my hands by a very generous Dutch bloke as I was leaving Zythos and I just couldnt wait and opened it on the train on the way back to Antwerp.Black colour with a short lived tan head. A huge slug of liquorice in the aroma with some damn fine sweet malt and heavy but lovely spice. Big but tolerable alcohol in the flavour with possibly the best liquorice flavours I have experienced in a beer. Thick chewy malt and not much of the 93.5 EBUs on show until a bit of bitterness towards the end. The finish has UNREAL length that just goes on and on and develops in an amazing fashion. It lingers for so long eventually maturing into some fresh unbrewed malt. Its like experiencing a growth of many differing vintages all in one go. This one is all about the finish and I love it. Massive thanks to Joris (joes) for this, MUCH appreciated sir!

On tap at the Brewery. Poured Black as night with a 2 finger brown head into a tulip glass. Mostly coffee aroma with hints of chocolate and smoke. It was also nice because my nose was filled with the smell of malt from the brewing room 20 feet from me. Flavor much the same as the aroma with some hints of caramel. A wonderful porter. If your ever in Bodegraven,  look for the windmill!!!

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2014 Not tasted in the best conditions as it was from a bottle into a ZBF glass on the train from St Niklaas back to Antwerp.  Very dark brown with no real head.  Choc stout aroma.  Pretty smooth in mouth.  Intense aroma, but pretty drinkable in mouth.  Some soy sauce, but not over the top.  Some nutty flavour too.  Very good.  Does not blow me away.  Lovely choc and coffee. 4.0
Keykeg at Kent BF2014. Wow. Chocolate intense.  Smooth. Thick in the mouth in a good way. Frankly amazing. Like chocolate milkshake without the milk. Pretty much amazing.
Bottle. Pitch black colour. Soft roasty malty smokish aroma.  Sticky mouthfeel. The flavour has smoke, well roasty burned malt with some bitterness. Yum!

Bottled, thanks to caesar. Opaque, black, no head whatsoever. Strong and complex aged aroma, roasted malts, peat, coffee, cognac its all in there, wonderful. Flavour however appears to be a lot more immature, lots of bitterness. Has more characteristics of a barley wine than a baltic porter. Like others have described previously, it tastes like it could use some more aging. Very nice brew, but in its current, fresh condition i personally wouldnt classify it as a top 50 brew.

Bottle @ Yespr tasting.[thank you, Yespr]
Pours almost black with almost no head. Aroma is complex and powerful. Lots of coffee, roasted malts, light chocolate. Very low carbonation, making it very oily. Falvour is sweet, vinious, coffee, light smokiness. Fabolous aftertaste, where the 11 % come to the fore without ever being alcoholic - which is quite an achievement. Perhaps this deserves a rerate with a bottle that has aged a year or two?

[Courtesy of yespr - session @ yespr] Black with tiny head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, liquerice, chocolate and coffee notes. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, liquerice, coffee and smoky notes. Ends rather sweet and bitter.

33 cl bottle, thanks to BierKönig for giving me this. Thick chocolate malt and light chalky aroma. Soldy alcohol presence and a light roasted note. Flavour is roasted and smoked flavour. Not much carbonation. Light fruity note. finish is dominated by smoked malt. Ends with a nice smoked and chocolate dominated flavour. Great.
Black coloured, almost no head. Aroma has mainly licorice, molasses and roasted malts. Very bitter taste, of coffee, malts and chocolate. Outstanding!

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 Finally got some bottles of the Tsarina Esra. Very dark, black colored brew, like black oil. Roasted, chocolat malty aroma and flavor. Coffee, licorice. Very nice porter. Going to re-rate in a couple of years :)

I drank this beer at the brewery in Bodegraven (lovely brewery and also restaurant) and at home in a bottle.
This is really the best dutch porter. I dont know how the brewer does it, but its really fantastic.
Chocolate, caramel, roasted mocha, little bit sweet powerful hop aroma

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2015 Tap @ de Molen, bottle @ home. Dark black color, short brown head. Intense aroma of roasted malt, some peat, chocolat, roasted coffee, some hop, bit tar and varnish. Strong oily taste of chocolat, coffee, roasted malts, very nicely balanced. Very bitter palate, oily. What a tribute.
Additional notes: had another bottle of at least 1 year old. Ages sublime. Aroma already has some delicious port notes in it, which match very well with chocolat and coffee.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2008 On tap @ the brewery, Bottle @ Home. Aroma has roast, coffee, chocolate, some raisin. Black coloured with a huge creamy, beige-brown head. The bottled version had much less head and it had larger bubbles. Its taste is sweet with a strong bitterness working its way towards the finish. It has chocolate, coffee, licorice.  Very oily texture, much more like the scandinavian and american imperial stout brews. Very well balanced and smooth beer. But I guess it can use a little more complexity. The beer is still very young, and a little more aging will provide this complexity I think. To be rerated. 
Rerate, previous rating 4.1. Aroma is a mixture of dried fruits, some licorice, bitter chocolate and some wine. Taste is quite on the sweet side with a lingering coffee/chocolate bitterness. Thick mouthfeel, but a dry aftertaste. Good beer.

A lush & dense stout, with layer after layer of coffee, licorice, chocolate, plum, caramel, maple syrup and oily hops. Keeps unfolding. In the finish there is more black fruit, along with vanilla and roasty bitterness. Great length; unmatched intensity, yet soft-edged and rounded; it is full-bodied and pours like ink. Spectacular.

Tap at PRZH Winterbierfestival, Gouda:
One of the best Imperial Russian Stout i evr drunk from out the Netherlands, Opaque black with yellow head, hints of chocolate, coffee and bitter.

Tap & bottle at the brewery. A wonderful beer with a brave plot which has been technically executed very well. Has the aroma of milk chocolate, a blend of varnish and liquors, raisins, vanilla and light cinnamon. Malty and yeasty aromas (dough) are light at first, yet get progressively stronger as the brew heats up. The malts are more intense in the bottled version. A jolt of coffee powder, cassis, cured leaves and dried twigs in the flavor  all oiled by varnish. Large, frothy luminescent-brown head. Too dense to leave any lace in the tap version: slips down the glass walls under its own weight. The lace is perfect in the bottled version. Feels pleasant oily, smooth. A slightly drying mouthfeel in the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 Bottle. Almost black and opague. Intense aroma of chocolate, licorice, mocha and dried fruit. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel. Very intense malty flavor with pepper, licorice, plums, dried fruit, mocha and porto. The alcohol is there, but very well hidden. Already an excellent beer, that will need a lot of time to fully develop its total potential and reveal its full beauty. Like a teenage girl with her beauty still in the bud, that can do a 500 pounds leg press. A quite memorable beer.

Second batch, from tap: more chocolate and dried fruit, less licorice as the first batch. Immensely malty, amazingly good. The rating is fully deserved.

From 750 ml bottle, after a year cellaring. Has turned just a bit vinous and the alcohol is totally hidden by the intense malty sweetness.

On draft at beer festival in Gouda. Defently the best beer of the festival. It started at 16.00 hours and there was a line till the end of the cask A splendid taste of sweet and bitterness. Very complex beer. This beer was a Russian Stout
